label: Bicycle Network Coverage
description: The percent of streets with bike lanes can affect cyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use.

label: Sidewalk Area
description: Sidewalks are a critical component of New York City residents’ commute. Ample sidewalks in neighborhoods are important for commuting, businesses, and physical activity. Greater sidewalk area facilitates safer pedestrian traffic that, in turn, attracts businesses and fosters community. “Sidewalk area” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered by sidewalk area.

label: Subway Station Density
description: Many New Yorkers rely on the subway as their primary mode of transportation. Neighborhoods with greater subway access tend to have more foot traffic, making surrounding real estate highly desirable for residents and business. Subway use encourages active transportation (walking, biking), which improves the health of residents.
message: Density of subway stations per km2.
The New York City Subway information was originally obtained from the New York
City Transit Authority in 1998. The data was realigned to the NYCMap basemap in 2002.
In November of 2006, a major shape update included PDF Subway System maps being
downloaded from the MTA/NYC Transit web-site. Community Cartography updated the

existing GIS files using on-screen digitizing and the downloaded subway maps. In August of 2007, station locations were spatially adjusted to align to the NYCMap streets at a map scale of 1:2,400. For more information, please visit the MTA Transit web-site at: www.mta.nyc.ny.us/nyct/maps/subwaymap.pdf.

label: Tree Canopy Cover
description: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. “Tree canopy cover” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

message: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. Tree canopy cover measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. The percent is calculated by dividing the area of tree canopy in km2 within the UHF neighborhood by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies). Higher percentages indicate greater tree canopy cover, with zero representing no tree canopy cover.

label: Vegetative Cover
description: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants. This area is not covered by a hard surface such as paved roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area.
message: Percent of area with vegetative cover, including grass and trees

label: Walkability Index (Infrastructure)
description: Walkability indices summarize built environment features believed to promote walking, focusing on neighborhood infrastructure. Some potentially important characteristics are usually not included, such as neighborhood safety or attractiveness, like number of street trees.
message: Summary indicator of built environment features believed to promote walking

description: For this index, higher scores indicate greater walkability. NYC neighborhoods range in walkability index (infrastructure) score from -4.0 to 9.4, with zero representing an approximate average for the City as a whole.

label: Walking Distance to a Park
description: Walking distance to a park is defined as 1/4-mile or less to entrances of smaller sites, such as sitting areas and playgrounds, and 1/2-mile or less to entrances of larger parks. Parks and open space that are not under the NYC Parks Department jurisdiction are also included.

Indicator: Walking Distance to a Subway Station
label: Walking Distance to a Subway Station
description: Percentage of population within a quarter-mile of a subway station entrance.
message: Walking distance to a subway station

label: Air Quality Advisory Days
message: Air Quality Advisory Days due to Ozone or PM 2.5 Levels above Regulatory Standard

label: Black Carbon
description: Black carbon is a major component of fine particulate matter (PM) in the air. Particulate matter is easily inhaled into the lungs and can contribute to both short-term acute health effects, as well as long-term chronic illness.

label: Fine Particulate Matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>)
description: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.

label: Nitric Oxide (NO)
description: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), which include nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), are a group of pollutants formed by combusion that can cause damage to lung tissue, breathing and respiratory problems, as well as contribute to smog and acid rain.

label: Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2)
description: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), which include nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), are a group of pollutants formed by combusion that can cause damage to lung tissue, breathing and respiratory problems, as well as contribute to smog and acid rain.

label: Ozone
message: Maximum 8-Hour Average Ozone Concentration over the National Ambient Air Quality Standard

label: Ozone (O3)
description: Ozone is a common air pollutant that can harm breathing and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions.

label: Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)
description: Sulfur dioxide comes from burning certain types of fuel oil. As an air pollutant, it can can worsen lung diseases.

label: Adults with asthma in the past 12 months
description: Asthma is a common disease characterized by breathing difficulty. Environmental exposures resulting from poor air quality and housing maintenance are known to increase risk of asthma development and trigger asthma symptoms. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.

label: Adults
description: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Certain exposures can trigger asthma symptoms, including smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander, among others.

Jail Incarceration
description: Each component of the criminal justice continuum - from arrest to re-entry - carries various health consequences, and a growing body of literature has documented severe adverse health outcomes associated with incarceration on the individual, their families, and neighbourhoods.

("Structural Racism and Health Inequities in the USA: Evidence and Interventions”, by Zinzi D Bailey, ScD; Professor Nancy Krieger, PhD; Madina Agénor, ScD; Jasmine Graves, MPH; Natalia Linos, ScD; and Dr. Mary T. Bassett, MD)

Daytime Summer Surface Temperature
description: Surface temperatures in NYC may vary as a function of vegetative land cover, which promotes cooling, or cover by paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings, which retain heat.

label: Heat Vulnerability Index
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

label: Heat Vulnerability Index by NTA
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

label: Court-Ordered Evictions
description: People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression, anxiety, and psychological distress. Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.
(From "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel)

label: Crowding (> 1 person/room)
description: Occupied housing units with more than one person per room are considered crowded.
message: Neighborhood Crowding (More than 1 Person per Room)

description: Building quality is a strong predictor of the number of housing maintenance deficiencies in a residence that may contribute to increased risk of acute or chronic health problems.

label: Homes using supplemental heat
description: The need for supplemental heat may mean a building's main heat source doesn't work - and can indicate the presence of other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies

Adults with Independent Living Difficulty
description: People with disabilities or access or functional needs may need additional support during extreme weather to avoid injury, illness or even death. For example, planning needs to be made for safe travel out of evacuation zones during a hurricane, or to ensure back-up electricity is available to to support medical equipment during power outages caused by heat waves.

Information provided here about adults with independent living difficulties can help emergency management professionals better prepare our residents for emergencies. For more information, please visit:
NYC Emergency Management: Disabilities, Access & Functional Needs

Indicator: Air Toxics Concentrations- Average Benzene Concentrations
label: Air Toxics Concentrations- Average Benzene Concentrations
description: Benzene is an air pollutant resulting from motor vehicle and industrial emissions and tobacco smoke. Benzene is a known carcinogen that can also harm bone marrow and red blood cell function.
message: Air Toxics Concentrations- Average Benzene Concentrations

Indicator: Air Toxics Concentrations- Average Formaldehyde Concentrations
label: Air Toxics Concentrations- Average Formaldehyde Concentrations

Neighborhood Poverty (ACS)
description: Neighborhood poverty measures residents' access to economic stability, education, adequate health care, safe housing and freedom from stress. Neighborhoods with higher poverty tend to have less access to these factors and experience worse health outcomes.
message: Neighborhood poverty based on UHF defined as percent of residents with incomes below 100% of the Federal Poverty Level, per American Community Survey.

label: Older Adults Living Alone
description: Adults over the age of 65 are more vulnerable to extreme hot and cold weather. Those that live alone may have more difficulty getting the resources they need in extreme weather events and are at higher risk of weather-related illnesses like heat stroke and hypothermia.

label: Poverty
description: Neighborhood poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

description: Sulfur dioxide comes from burning certain types of fuel oil. As an air pollutant, it can can worsen lung diseases.

label: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.
message: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled (VMT)

Indicator: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Cars
label: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Cars
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.
message: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled (VMT) for Cars

Indicator: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
label: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

label: Tree Canopy Cover
description: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. “Tree canopy cover” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

message: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. Tree canopy cover measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. The percent is calculated by dividing the area of tree canopy in km2 within the UHF neighborhood by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies). Higher percentages indicate greater tree canopy cover, with zero representing no tree canopy cover.

label: Vegetative Cover
description: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants. This area is not covered by a hard surface such as paved roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area.
message: Percent of area with vegetative cover, including grass and trees

label: Obese Adults
description: People who are obese are at increased risk for heart disease and diabetes. Neighborhood factors such as walkability and the types of food retail outlets available can impact residents' risk of being overweight or obese.

label: Overweight or Obese Adults
description: People who are overweight or obese are at increased risk for heart disease and diabetes.

label: Adults Reporting Personal Pesticide Use

Indicator: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
label: "Best Practice" Products
description: NYC enacted a local law in 2005 that requires city agencies to reduce use of toxic products to control pests, and to adopt “Best Practices” instead. Best practice products use active ingredients with very low toxicity or involve formulation or application methods that minimize potential exposure and environmental spread.
message: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products

label: Mosquito Control

label: Adults with Health Insurance
description: Health insurance coverage is associated with numerous beneficial health effects. Those with health insurance are more likely to have a regular doctor, receive preventive care services, better manage chronic health conditions, have longer life expectancy, and more.

label: Adults with Independent Living Difficulty
description: People with disabilities or access or functional needs may need additional support during extreme weather to avoid injury, illness or even death. For example, planning needs to be made for safe travel out of evacuation zones during a hurricane, or to ensure back-up electricity is available to to support medical equipment during power outages caused by heat waves.

Information provided here about adults with independent living difficulties can help emergency management professionals better prepare our residents for emergencies. For more information, please visit:
NYC Emergency Management: Disabilities, Access & Functional Needs

Indicator: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
label: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
description: Poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

label: Court-Ordered Evictions
description: People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression, anxiety, and psychological distress. Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.
(From "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel)

label: Crowding (> 1 person/room)
description: Occupied housing units with more than one person per room are considered crowded.
message: Neighborhood Crowding (More than 1 Person per Room)

label: Older Adults Living Alone
description: Adults over the age of 65 are more vulnerable to extreme hot and cold weather. Those that live alone may have more difficulty getting the resources they need in extreme weather events and are at higher risk of weather-related illnesses like heat stroke and hypothermia.

label: Perception of Neighborhood Safety
description: Whether people perceive their neighborhood as safe can affect whether they will spend time outside, use parks, and use active and sustainable forms of transportation. It can also affect mental well-being.

label: Poverty
description: Neighborhood poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

Bicycle Injury Emergency Department Visits

label: Babesiosis
description: Babesiosis is a rare, sometimes severe or fatal tick-borne disease caused by Babesia microti, a protozoan parasite that infects red blood cells. Babesiosis is transmitted by the bite of an infected blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, the same tick that transmits Lyme disease and anaplasmosis.  Most patients acquire this disease while traveling to endemic areas outside NYC. However, there has been an increase in the number of cases with no history of travel to endemic areas, primarily in Staten Island, as well as isolated cases in the Bronx and Queens. Babesiosis can also be transmitted through transfused blood products.
For more information
NYC DOHMH Babesiosis Page
NYC DOHMH Zoonotic and Vector-borne Diseases
CDC Babesiosis
National Surveillance Babesiosis Case Definition

label: West Nile virus
description: West Nile virus (WNV) is an arbovirus which is transmitted through the bite of infected mosquitoes; in NYC, the mosquitoes that transmit WNV are primarily Culex pipiens as well as Culex restuans and Culex salinarius. While most people who are infected will not go on to develop symptoms, about 20% can experience mild or moderate illness and more rarely, neuroinvasive disease which can present as encephalitis or meningitis.  Most of the West Nile disease cases detected by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene represent neuroinvasive disease as these patients are more likely to seek care.   More specific West Nile viral disease data is available on the Health Department website.

label: Non-fatal Assault Emergency Department Visits
description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in emergency department visits are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

label: Non-fatal Assault Hospitalizations
description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in hospitalizations are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

description: Hospitalizations due to heat stress represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

label: Heat Vulnerability Index
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

label: Heat Vulnerability Index by NTA
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

Indicator: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among Persons Aged 16 or Older
label: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among  Persons Aged 16 or Older
description: In New York City, the most common cause of lead poisoning in non-pregnant adults is from occupational exposure in the construction industry. Workers are exposed by breathing in or ingesting lead dust or fumes during renovations, repairs and demolitions that disturb old, lead based paint. Workers in other industries, as well as hobbyists, may be at risk if they work with lead-containing metal, paint, pigments, ceramic glazes or bullets. Adults can also be exposed to lead through the use of lead-contaminated products, such as certain imported health remedies or medicines, spices, foods, pottery and cosmetics.
message: Employed adults with elevated blood lead levels

label: Hospitalizations Billed to Workers’ Compensation
description: Workers’ compensation is a type of insurance that provides medical care for workers who are injured or become ill as a direct result of their job. Hospitalizations billed to workers' compensation represent only a portion of work-related injuries that require hospital care. It is important to realize that workers’ compensation policies vary from state-to-state with respect to the types of workers covered and the types of injuries and illnesses eligible for compensation.

label: Hospitalizations for Asbestosis
description: Asbestos is a naturally-occurring mineral which was commonly used as an insulation material until the 1970s. Inhaling high concentrations of asbestos fibers over a long time can produce lung inflammation and scarring resulting in the chronic lung disease called asbestosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. New York City construction, insulation, and shipyard workers who installed, disturbed, or removed asbestos without respiratory protection are at risk. Additionally, smokers who are exposed to asbestos have a greater risk of developing asbestos-related diseases than non-smokers.

Typically it takes more than ten years from the time of exposure before symptoms develop. The use of proper protective masks is key to preventing the disease, since there is no treatment for this condition.

label: Hospitalizations for Pneumoconiosis
description: Pneumoconiosis is a general term given to any lung disease caused by breathing in certain particles or fibers over a prolonged period. Pneumoconiosis usually results from a workplace exposure  The most common causes of pneumoconiosis include asbestos fibers (asbestosis), silica dust (silicosis), and coal dust (coal workers’ pneumoconiosis or “Black Lung Disease”). There is no cure, but it can be prevented with appropriate respiratory protection.

label: Perception of Neighborhood Safety
description: Whether people perceive their neighborhood as safe can affect whether they will spend time outside, use parks, and use active and sustainable forms of transportation. It can also affect mental well-being.

label: Work-Related Deaths across All Industries
description: Fatal work-related injuries include deaths resulting from unintentional injuries such as falls, acute poisonings, and motor vehicle crashes that occur during travel for work, and intentional injuries (i.e., homicides and suicides) that occur at work. Fatal injuries that occur during a person’s commute to or from work are not included.

Data on work-related deaths are compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries (CFOI). CFOI produces statistics on fatal work-related injuries by cross-referencing multiple sources, such as death certificates, workers' compensation reports, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) investigation reports.

Indicator: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry by Borough
label: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry by Borough of Injury.
description: The New York City workforce is a diverse one and workplace risks are not distributed equally. Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, accounting for nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year.

Indicator: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry Citywide
label: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry Citywide
description: The New York City workforce is a diverse one and workplace risks are not distributed equally. Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, accounting for nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year. Falls from scaffolds, ladders and roofs are the most common cause of fatal injuries among construction workers.
